title: Graphical analysis - effect of Montreal Protocol

content.question: Which of the following statements best uses the data to support the claim that the Montreal Protocol was an effective solution for a global problem?

choices.label: The Montreal Protocol reduced stratospheric ozone depletion by increasing the reliance on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in industrial processes. Based on the graph, the increase in global <math alttext="C F C " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production from 1960 to 1970 demonstrates the success of the protocol by substituting ozone-depleting substances with <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The Montreal Protocol was passed in 1970 to increase the production of <math alttext="H C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which led to decreased reliance on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the graph, <math alttext="H C F C 22" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCFC-</mtext><mn>22</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> production increased steadily from 1980 to 1990 and <math alttext="H C F C 141 b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCFC-</mtext><mn>141</mn><mtext>b</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increased from 1990 to 2000.

The Montreal Protocol led to a dramatic reduction in <math alttext="C F C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production globally after 1987, which greatly reduced the concentration of chlorinated hydrocarbons present in the stratosphere and decreased the breakdown of stratospheric ozone. Based on the graph, the annual production of <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> decreased significantly in the late 1980s to almost <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> tons by 2000.

The Montreal Protocol monitored the production and sale of <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the late 1990s to decrease tropospheric ozone pollution and photochemical smog. Based on the graph, <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> leveled off at <math alttext="100,000" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> tons produced in 2000.
